abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Provincial Roads Project
            for Sri Lanka were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was substantial,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: it is critical that good quality detailed
            engineering designs, bidding documents, environmental, and
            social safeguards documents are prepared during project
            preparation and procurement completed for key contracts and
            consultancies. Enhancing capacity of the internal audit must
            be given special focus in future projects through
            institutional strengthening and capacity building component.
            The local contractors’ capacity was heavily overstretched
            due to increased amount of funding being channeled in to
            large infrastructure projects. Ad-measured, item-rate civil
            works contracts frequently encounter major cost over-runs,
            due to significant variations in final work quantities and
            delays in project implementation. The environmental
            assessment at appraisal should address the vulnerability of
            roads to landslides. Learning from the experience of
            landslide stabilization in Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, and
            India, cost-effective soil bioengineering and biotechnical
            measures for remediating slope instability should have been applied.
